summary: The document is a transcript of testimony by Alfred J. Sarno detailing his involvement with the CIA, particularly focusing on the AMOT program, a group of Cuban exiles engaged in intelligence gathering and operations in Miami and other locations. Sarno discusses the AMOT group's structure, their roles in debriefing Cuban refugees, collecting intelligence on Cuba, and their interactions with the CIA and FBI. The testimony also covers the setup of a stay-behind network in Cuba before diplomatic relations were severed, the training of AMOT members, and a specific incident involving a plot to attack the UN building. Sarno denies any involvement in illegal activities or connections with organized crime.
key_findings: Alfred J. Sarno managed the CIA's AMOT group of Cuban exiles in Miami, focusing on intelligence collection and debriefing.
The AMOT group was involved in debriefing Cuban refugees and collecting intelligence on Cuba, with no admitted involvement in surveillance or counterintelligence against Castro agents.
A notable incident involved the AMOT group uncovering a plot to attack the UN building, which was reported to the FBI.
Sarno discussed the training of AMOT members in basic tradecraft but denied training in surveillance or surreptitious entry techniques.
Before diplomatic relations with Cuba were severed, Sarno was involved in setting up a stay-behind network in Cuba.
Sarno denied any knowledge or involvement in illegal activities or connections with organized crime.
The testimony highlights the careful delineation of operations to avoid overlap with the FBI's jurisdiction, especially concerning Cuban diplomats at the UN.
